Issues.Title: Clean / reliably possibility to detect template issues
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

_No response_

### Description

If I'm not mistaken, there is no clean solution to determine runtime template errors (I tried to find a solution via [Stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/77821169/angular-how-to-detect-equal-template-errors/77821381)). I can only check the stack for keywords and compare two errors' stacks to tell they are equal.

I'm using a custom error handler to show runtime errors in the client. If the error is caused by the template (e.g. null pointer reference), I end up in an endless loop because the dialog (mat snack) triggers the templating engine again.

### Proposed solution

Mark the thrown error as a template error (or create a custom error class to tell it apart by its type) and pass it some kind of Id that identifies the error.

### Alternatives considered

Maybe there already is a solution for this? A link to the code handling template errors would be great.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Clean / reliably possibility to detect template issues" (#53932)

Issues.Title: Service provided by NgModule in standalone workspace is not singleton in unit tests
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

I am working in a standalone workspace which imports some third party NgModules, as they didn't migrate to standalone yet. In their `providers` they sometimes have singleton services. When writing unit tests involving these services, I recognized that if a standalone component imports such a module, the constructor of the component returns a different instance of the service than the `TestBed.inject()` function in the unit test. Issues.Title: Support setting Application Badge from Service workers
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

service-worker

### Description

Currently you can use Push notification for displaying notification messages. But it is not possible to change application badge from push notification when application is not started. 
You can use setAppBadge from SwPush.messages, but this only works when application is already running. 


### Proposed solution

Support setting application badge natively in ngsw-worker.js. New push payload would look something like this:
```typescript
{
  "notification": {
    "actions": NotificationAction[],
    ....
  },
  "appBadge": number | undefined
}
```
If appBadge property is not set nothing will happened, but if it is set, then inside "push" event, self.navigator.setAppBadge should be called with value of "appBadge". Setting "appBadge" to 0, will clear badge.


### Alternatives considered

Now the only way to change application badge when application is offline is to use custom service worker to handle "push" event and then import ngsw-worker.js. But I'm not sure that even this will work on WebKit, because as stated in https://webkit.org/blog/14112/badging-for-home-screen-web-apps/ and if I understand correctly, both showNotification and setAppBadge must be 'promise' from same "push" event.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Support setting Application Badge from Service workers" (#53920)

Issues.Title: Hydration resets state of reactive forms
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

forms, platform-server

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

Ran into this when upgrading my Angular app to 16 and replacing [Angular Preboot](https://github.com/angular/preboot) with hydration.

When an SSR'd application renders and the user interacts with some reactive form elements, these form elements are reset to their initial state when the app fully bootstraps. This makes sense since the Angular reactive forms aren't active while the app is bootstrapping.

Angular Preboot used to fix this by replaying (? - not sure exactly how it worked) the DOM events, so the form state would be re-entered when the page was transitioned from the SSR view to the client-rendered view.

This functionality doesn't seem to be available in Angular 16 or 17 with client hydration. This makes the UX for SSRed pages with forms (eg. a login page) pretty bad, as the form can empty itself in the middle of a user typing.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://github.com/henry-alakazhang/hydration-form-repro

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
- Run `yarn start` to serve the application with SSR and hydration
- Throttle network in browser to make sure there's a delay between initial load and client hydration
- Modify the form controls while the app is bootstrapping

Expected:
- Both inputs retain their values after hydration

Actual:
- The input with a `FormControl` is reset to the default `FormControl` value.
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI: 17.0.10
Node: 18.19.0
Package Manager: yarn 1.22.19
OS: darwin arm64

Angular: 17.0.9
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, platform-server
... router

---------------------------------------------------------
```

Issues.Title: mat-table sort arrows are disproportionate and have rendering bugs
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

For our WebApp, we made the jump from Angular 13 to Angular 16 with all the needed migrations in between. One regression we spotted is the mat-table sort arrow looking markably worse, not just in our case, but the Angular Samples in the official documentation too. The arrow used to be a unicode glyph, but is now an amalgamation of 3 separate rectangular boxes. As a result this introduces a row of rendering bugs, depending on device, browser, zoom level, dpi etc.

- The arrow does not look the same from column to column, changing appearance between columns
- The arrow has lost its symmetrical form
  - https://material.angular.io/components/sort/overview: ![image](https://github.com/angular/angular/assets/60887273/0855a9f3-bca1-4abf-ba8b-90774606d6ed)
  - Our case: ![image](https://github.com/angular/angular/assets/60887273/69ceebe9-427d-41eb-b9eb-300948df4172)
- The arrow has a flat top or sometimes even holes where the two rectangles meet in rare cases, on a specific combination of browser, zoom level, dpi etc.

https://material.angular.io/components/sort/overview

Issues.Title: Unexplained DOM Node accumulation and performance degradation in Angular 17 while routing between pages
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

Don't known / other

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

When navigating between my pages in my application using `this.router.navigate`, my DOM Nodes are increasing and the whole application eventually starts to slow down (Especially animations and transitions). 

This happens mostly on Chrome, but also happens in Edge and Firefox but a lot better, takes more time to make it slow, or navigating between bigger pages with more elements.

I have another app in the company that is a lot bigger than the app I write now with Angular 17, and is written with Angular 13 and has way more content and heavier pages, written very similar and this doesn't happen, nodes getting cleared eventually and nothing slows down.

I am not sure how to fix this, after long researching.

I unsubscribe on destroys, I destroy unused components (actually it does it automatically on navigating), I use trackBy, I use a lot of ngIfs for skeleton loaders though, not sure if it can cause an issue. I don't use the new control flow.

Issues.Title: Angular SSR not waiting for HTTP request
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

platform-server

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

We have upgraded to Angular 17 recently and noticed that some parts of your DOM stopped getting rendered in SSR.

On some pages this behavior was consisted - sections that ware always present before the upgrade stopped getting rendered.

On other pages it looked like a race condition - sometimes it rendered sometimes it did not.

No error messages in the logs.

We added an interceptor to log everything that happened around HTTP API calls done by HttpClient and we noticed that some requests got there observables unsubscribed and never logged a response from the server. Our server logs on the other hand reported that the server has correctly responded in ~100ms.

On forums we noted that some resolved this problem by wrapping their API call to ensure they are macrotasks. Eg.: https://stackoverflow.com/a/66699719

I've also notices this article: https://dev.to/krisplatis/angular-ssr-v16-saying-goodbye-to-a-sneaky-trick-macrotask-wrapping-for-http-calls-487b

from which I understand that Angular stopped doing that because of a better solution. I don't think however that it works.

We found a more elegant solution by adding `provideHttpClient(withFetch())` to ours `AppServerModeul` providers <- theoretically this should have not changed anything but practice it solved the problem.

In conclusion I think that there is a bug lurking here or at least the documentation should state that   `provideHttpClient(withFetch())` is not only the preferred way but the required way for a working SSR app.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

_No response_

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

_No response_

Issues.Title: Angular.dev tutorial uses `fetch` for HTTP requests, but this doesn't seem to work well with Interceptors
Issues.Body:
### Describe the problem that you experienced

In the new tutorial for Angular 17 on https://angular.dev/, the _Build your first Angular app_ tutorial uses the `fetch` api in the _Add HTTP Communication_ section. However, as I am looking into building things like interceptors into my app, they don't seem to play well with the fetch API.

Could a note be added about the downsides of using the fetch API? Or, if I am missing something about interceptors (and other features that are included with the HttpClient) can notes be added to the tutorial about how to use these features?

### Enter the URL of the topic with the problem

Issues.Title: Condider making first argument of input() mandatory
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

core

### Description

There is a difference in the design of the `input()` and of the `signal()` functions.

`signal<T>()` expects an argument and returns a `Signal<T>`, whereas `input<T>()` can be called with or without argument and returns a `Signal<T | undefined>` if no argument is passed.

Moreover, if we have code that uses `input()` without argument:

```ts
collapsed = input<boolean>();
```

and want to pass it options, then suddenly we're forced to 
- pass an initial value, although the initial value is the same as before;
- change the generic type passed to the function, even though the type of the signal to create is the same as before:

```ts
collapsed = input<boolean | undefined>(undefined, { alias: 'appCollapsed' });
```


### Proposed solution

Even though it requires a bit more code, I find the the result would be more consistent, more explicit, and less surprising if `input()` always required an initial value:

```ts
collapsed = input<boolean | undefined>(undefined);
```

- adding options requires just that: adding options
- the generic type is the same as the generic type of the created Signal
- it works the same way as signal()


### Alternatives considered

NA
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Condider making first argument of input() mandatory" (#53909)

Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

platform-server, router

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

Most of the websites preferred SSR , optimised and SEO right ? I am super duper excited in angular 17 for SSR but one thing today when I built and deployed on server then SSR are only working in static routes only . 

What I mean by that ? 
   - SSR working in static route
      - Example : /blogs
   - Not working in dynamic routes
      - Example : /blog/:slug
         - Here in locally when when accessing route like
           -  /blog/what-is-ssr   
           - /blog/dynamic-route-in-angular-v17  
                 Then SSR working but after **ng build** deploying **_dist/(browser) folder in server then after accessing route_** 
        -  /blog/what-is-ssr   
        - /blog/dynamic-route-in-angular-v17  
           then only getting content index.html content. 

Please fix this or if already it's done but I wrongly build and deployed then please guide me.

You can see my deployed project here and [https://alal.test.ahatech1.cloud/](https://alal.test.ahatech1.cloud/). 


Thank you

Issues.Title: Add support for postcss-rtlcss for angular build
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Description

A common issue faced by the arab and rtl speaking communities is that angular limits the postcss configs, and therefore it prevents their ability to use the industry standard [rtlcss](https://rtlcss.com/index.html). In other frameworks like react the user is able to configure the postcss configs and therefore is able to use tool like [postcss-rtlcss](https://www.npmjs.com/package/postcss-rtlcss)

To support the argument further, we can take a look at one of the most popular [bootstrap](https://getbootstrap.com/docs/5.3/getting-started/rtl/) and their recommendation of using rtlcss 

### Describe the solution you'd like

As we understand angular team would like to maintain exclusive control over the postcss configuration. We would like to see a similar implementation to the solution provided for tailwind by looking for a specific config file such as `rtlcss.config` and adding it to the list of postcss plugins if it exists.

A similar approach on how angular handles the [tailwind plugin ](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/e871f87fa2eda5cdf74557b95b47aa419e53e17b/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/webpack/configs/styles.ts#L164)

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Currently we were relying on custom webpack overriding libraries such as [ngx-build-plus](https://github.com/manfredsteyer/ngx-build-plus), however these are broken with the new build system and therefore it would be best if angular provide an official support for rtlcss plugin
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add support for postcss-rtlcss for angular build" (#26867)

Issues.Title: new text loader in 17.1.0-rc.1 doesn't load files from node_modules
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Is this a regression?

- No

### Description

Using the new loader support in version 17.1 to load the content of a file as text using an import statement works fine, but not when the file is under node_modules, unless using a complete relative path such as `../../node_modules/bootstrap-icons/icons/save.svg`.

When using the path that looks more logical to me (`bootstrap-icons/icons/save.svg`), then the CLI outputs a warning in the console:

> Cannot optimize dependency: bootstrap-icons/icons/save.svg, present in 'optimizeDeps.include'

and instead of loading the file content, it loads the text `/@fs/home/projects/stackblitz-starters-ycv7cm/repro/node_modules/bootstrap-icons/icons/save.svg`

### Minimal Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-ycv7cm?file=repro%2Fsrc%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.ts

- npm i
- ng serve

Issues.Title: refactor(@angular-devkit/build-angular): allow internal Angular compilation control of diagnostic modes
Issues.Body: To support generate diagnostics in varying ways, the internal compilation classes now support a `modes` argument when diagnosing files during a build using the `application` builder. This is not exposed as an option at this time but can be experimented with a build using the `NG_BUILD_TYPE_CHECK` environment variable. This environment variable is not considered part of the public API and may be removed or altered in the future. Its current purpose is to allow profiling of the type checking diagnostics functionality of the build system.

Issues.Title: fix(@angular/cli): fixes Yarn v2 support for registry configuration
Issues.Body:
Adds support for `yarnrc.yml` files so that users of Yarn v2+ who attempt to run `ng add` or `ng update` do not experience a bug where the incorrect registry file extension (.yarnrc) is selected.

Fixes #23448

## PR Checklist

Please check to confirm your PR fulfills the following requirements:

<!-- Please check all that apply using "x". -->

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#-commit-message-guidelines
- [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [x] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)

## PR Type

What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [x] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:

## What is the current behavior?
Currently repositories using Yarn v2 or higher do not use the correct registry configuration file format, which causes issues when running ng-cli commands that require access to private repositories. See:
[https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/23448](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/23448)

Issue Number: 23448

## What is the new behavior?

The `ng add` and `ng update` commands check the correct file format (`yarnrc.yml`) for any repositories using Yarn version 2 or higher.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

<!-- If this PR contains a breaking change, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications below. -->

## Other information

Issues.Title: Shared assets across locales
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Description

I am using `@angular-devkit/build-angular:application` with `"assets"` and `"localize": true`.

The way these options interact, each locale gets its own separate directory in `./dist/<appName>/browser/<locale>/` and there's no way to place shared assets at the root of the browser directory `./dist/<appName>/browser`.

This means in particular that if I define `"assets": ["./src/favicon.ico"]`, it gets placed at paths such as `/en-US/favicon.ico` and not `/favicon.ico` (this breaks the expected file location).

### Describe the solution you'd like

Shared and localized assets should be differentiated, probably by adding an option to `assetPattern`. This should control if the output is relative to the browser root or localized dir.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

A workaround is to have a manual post-build step to copy the assets, but it's messy.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Shared assets across locales" (#26853)

Issues.Title: fix: ignore custom Jest configuration file and warn if one is found
Issues.Body:
Refs #25434.

Currently with Jest we're experimenting with whether or not Angular CLI can meet user needs without exposing the underlying configuration file. See https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/25434#issuecomment-1610298235 for more context.

If hiding the Jest configuration is a challenge for you, please consider if an alternative approach _without_ hooking into the Jest config is reasonable. Otherwise please post your use case to https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/25434 so we can evaluate the best path forward for this feature.

Jest was incorrectly picking up custom configurations, even though they exist outside Jest's root directory. This commit fixes that behavior so Jest does not see user configurations and does not apply them. Ideally we would throw an error if a Jest configuration is found to be more clear that it isn't doing what developers expect. However they may use a Jest config to run other projects in the same workspace outside of Angular CLI and we don't want to prevent that. A warning seems like the best trade off of notifying users that a custom config isn't supported while also not preventing unrelated Jest usage in the same workspace.

I've noticed a few issues where users were using a custom config either causing a problem or attempting to solve one. I want to be up front during the experimentation process what our current stance is for users playing around with Jest so we can collect feedback on how it impacts users earlier.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix: ignore custom Jest configuration file and warn if one is found" (#26852)

Issues.Title: Multiple projects in Angular workspace don't get tested by running ng test without a project name
Issues.Body:
### Command

test

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

It's been a while but this is a documented feature... :(

### Description

As per documentation https://angular.io/cli/test

ng test [project]
ng t [project]

Takes the name of the project, as specified in the projects section of the angular.json workspace configuration file. When a project name is not supplied, it will execute for all projects.

In practice it doesn't.

### Minimal Reproduction

ng new repro-app --no-create-application
cd repro-app
ng generate application admin --defaults
ng generate application www --defaults
ng test

End result is that only tests from admin project are run.

_No response_

Issues.Title: Inlining of critical CSS `ng build` optimization
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

~~Inlining of critical CSS is one of the optimizations applied by default when running `ng build`.~~

~~The non-critical CSS should be deferred, i.e. fetched asynchronously.
Here is the Angular implementation for this:~~

```html
<link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css" media="all" onload="this.media='all'">
```

~~Unfortunately, this stylesheet link will block rendering and its `onload` handler is a no-op.~~
~~I'm wondering if this is intentional or an actual bug.~~

~~The [loadCSS](https://github.com/filamentgroup/loadCSS) project recommends this code:~~

```html
<link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css" media="print" onload="this.media='all'; this.onload=null;">
```

~~They also have a [blog post](https://www.filamentgroup.com/lab/load-css-simpler/) explaining the logic behind it.~~

### Minimal Reproduction

N/A

### Exception or Error

_No response_

### Your Environment


_No response_

Issues.Title: bug(mat-table): sort arrows are disproportionate and have rendering bugs
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

The sort arrow is an amalgamation of 3 separate rectangular boxes. As a result this introduces a row of rendering bugs, depending on device, browser, zoom level, dpi etc.

- The arrow does not look the same from column to column, changing appearance between columns
- The arrow loses symmetrical form
  - https://material.angular.io/components/sort/overview: ![image](https://github.com/angular/angular/assets/60887273/0855a9f3-bca1-4abf-ba8b-90774606d6ed)
  - Our case: ![image](https://github.com/angular/angular/assets/60887273/69ceebe9-427d-41eb-b9eb-300948df4172)
- The arrow has a flat top or sometimes even holes where the two rectangles meet in rare cases, on a specific combination of browser, zoom level, dpi etc. 

I wish it was rather one single unicode glyph to side-step rendering issues, though I recognize the issue in animating that.

### Reproduction

Take a look at the sample in https://material.angular.io/components/sort/overview

### Expected Behavior

Arrow should look proportional, as before in 13.x.x

### Actual Behavior

Arrow changes proportion from column to column

### Environment

Node: 21.5.0 (Unsupported)
Package Manager: npm 9.3.0

Issues.Title: bug(mat-sidenav): Focus leaves side-nav if position is set to end
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

When using `mat-sidenav` the focus is not trapped in the side-nav if the `position` value is set to "end".

The behavior works properly when the `position` value is not set, or the `position` value is set to "start".

The user's focus is trapped on the first-tabbable element, but when the user continues to use keyboard navigation the focus leaves the sidenav and jumps to the url bar and then behind the side-nav.

### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-dpn6ep?file=src%2Findex.html

### Expected Behavior

The focus should remain trapped in the `mat-sidenav` if the `position` is set to "end" or "start" with all other values remaining the same. 

### Actual Behavior

The focus will leave the side-nav if the `position` is set to `end` with all other values remaining the same. 

### Environment

- Angular: 16
- CDK/Material: 16
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOs
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(mat-sidenav): Focus leaves side-nav if position is set to end" (#28409)

Issues.Title: Backport ripple memory leak fix to LTS
Issues.Body:
Backports an existing fix from 17.0.x to 16.2.x.

The `MatRippleLoader` that is used in the button doesn't track any ripples, but instead patches the ripples onto the DOM nodes which in theory should avoid leaks since the ripple will be collected together with the node. The problem is that each ripple registers itself with the `RippleEventManager` which needs to be notified on destroy so that it can dereference the DOM nodes and remove the event listeners.

These changes avoid the leaks by:
1. Destroying the ripple when the trigger is destroyed.
2. Cleaning up all the ripples when the ripple loader is destroyed.
3. No longer patching directives onto the DOM nodes.

Fixes #28240.

(cherry picked from commit a962bb77f2e68b44e4e3ccf88841f63495661036)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Backport ripple memory leak fix to LTS" (#28408)

Issues.Title: bug(Paginator): Form Field density is not propagated to the Page Size Select Form Field
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

When a different than default (higher) Form Field and Paginator density is applied, the Select Form Field inside the Paginator that serves to select the page size remains to have the same (default) height (42px). 


### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/iyuv6n?file=src%2Fexample%2Fpaginator-overview-example.html
Steps to reproduce:
1. open the StackBlitz link
2. check last lines of the theme.scss file where the code that is supposed to change the density of the Paginator and Form Field is applied
3. visually compare the heights of the Select Form Field inside the Paginator with the one that is outside the Paginator


### Expected Behavior

For example if `@include mat.form-field-density(-6);` is applied, the Form Fields should have 36px (without the Subscript Wrapper).

### Actual Behavior

The Select Form Field inside the Paginator has 42px height.

### Environment

- Angular: 17.0.0
- CDK/Material: 17.0.4
- Browser(s): all
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): all
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(Paginator): Form Field density is not propagated to the Page Size Select Form Field" (#28398)

Issues.Title: fix(material/core): fix mat-error not rendering with Closure Compiler
Issues.Body:
Fix Closure Compiler issue with <mat-error/>. Fix issue where <mat-error/> does not render.

Existing behavior is that _ErrorStateTracker sometimes reports error state as false when there is an error. This happens because Closure Compiler renames the _ErrorStateTracker's ErrorStateMatcher. The compiler renames all the other implementations of ErrorStateMatcher, but they have different names. Causes the matcher to be null in _ErrorStateTracker. Since ErrorStateMatcher is used as a class in some situations, Closure Compiler is not aware that it is intended to be the same type as the other implementations of ErrorStateMather.

Fix issue by declaring ErrorStateMatcher as an interface. When this commit applied, <mat-error/> will render when built with Closure Compiler.

Googlers: see [internal issue report](b/316413299)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material/core): fix mat-error not rendering with Closure Compiler" (#28405)

Issues.Title: bug(form-field): red border-left leaking over .mdc-notched-outline__notch
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

The mat input form label sometimes has a border on the left when the form field is in a error state and is empty so the label is not floating and the hover state is active.

![glitch1](https://github.com/angular/components/assets/25107583/eddb1918-4bf7-4868-bf64-14fe08d76eea)

The border color from:
```
.mdc-text-field--outlined.mdc-text-field--invalid:not(.mdc-text-field--disabled):not(.mdc-text-field--focused):hover .mdc-notched-outline .mdc-notched-outline__leading, 
.mdc-text-field--outlined.mdc-text-field--invalid:not(.mdc-text-field--disabled):not(.mdc-text-field--focused):hover .mdc-notched-outline .mdc-notched-outline__notch, 
.mdc-text-field--outlined.mdc-text-field--invalid:not(.mdc-text-field--disabled):not(.mdc-text-field--focused):hover .mdc-notched-outline .mdc-notched-outline__trailing {
	border-color: var(--mdc-outlined-text-field-error-hover-outline-color);
}
```
With a specificity of `Specificity: (0,7,0)` is taking priority over:
```
.mat-mdc-form-field.mat-mdc-form-field.mat-mdc-form-field.mat-mdc-form-field.mat-mdc-form-field.mat-mdc-form-field .mdc-notched-outline__notch {
	border-left: 1px solid transparent;
}
```
With it's specificity of `Specificity: (0,7,0)`.

The note on the `.mdc-notched-outline__notch` class suggests this is sufficient.
https://github.com/crisbeto/material2/blob/e8b0f416cc714c1922118d7f40b706f37793fb01/src/material/form-field/_mdc-text-field-structure-overrides.scss#L162
```
// Note: class name is repeated to achieve sufficient specificity over the various MDC states.
```

But it may not be. If I add one more `.mat-mdc-form-field`, then the rule's specificity `Specificity: (0,8,0)` is sufficient to bring the style rule above the other, which solves my issue

### Reproduction

I'm having trouble recreating the issue in a stack blitz. I think it is happening due to the order of module loading or the order the scss gets compiled to css, and thus the order that the styles get placed in the DOM. When I try to set it up in a stack blitz, the order of the two rules is reversed. I'm not sure what we could be doing to make the `form-field.mjs` load before the `_form-field-theme.scss`/`_mdc-text-field-structure-overrides.scss`

### Expected Behavior

no border left on .mdc-notched-outline__notch

### Actual Behavior

Some blead through of error-border on .mdc-notched-outline__notch

### Environment

- Angular: 16.2.10
- CDK/Material: 16.2.10 (still an issue after upgrading to 17)
- Browser(s): Chrome  120.0.6099.200 (not an issue on firefox)
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(form-field): red border-left leaking over .mdc-notched-outline__notch" (#28404)
